title: How to Get Sweat Stains out of Clothing

steps.title: Flip your item of clothing inside out and place it in a bowl or sink.
steps.content: Flip your item of clothing inside out and place it in a bowl or sink. Flipping your item of clothing inside out will allow you to attack the stain directly. Place your reversed item of clothing inside a large bowl or sink, with the stain resting at the lowest point in the bowl or sink. [1] X Research source This method will not work with spandex, which can be damaged by hot water. Using baking soda and hydrogen peroxide may cause discoloration if you’re removing stains from colored fabric.

steps.title: Combine baking soda, hydrogen peroxide, and water in a separate bowl.
steps.content: Combine baking soda, hydrogen peroxide, and water in a separate bowl. Use 1 part baking soda, 1 part hydrogen peroxide, and 1 part water in a large bowl and mix them together with a large clean spoon. Mix the solution until there are no visible chunks of baking soda left. [2] X Research source About 1 ⁄ 4 cup (59 mL) of each ingredient will be enough for 1 shirt or pair of pants.

steps.title: Boil a pot of water and pour it directly on the stains.
steps.content: Boil a pot of water and pour it directly on the stains. Fill a large pot with water and heat it on the stove until the water reaches a rolling boil. While wearing an oven mitt, carry the pot over to your sink or bowl and pour the boiling water directly over your sweat stain. This will loosen the fabric and make the sweat stains easier to scrub away. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Pour the baking soda solution directly on to the stain and scrub it.
steps.content: Pour the baking soda solution directly on to the stain and scrub it. With a spoon, scoop your solution directly on top of the stains. Let it soak for at least 5 minutes. After it soaks, scrub the stain with a scrub brush or toothbrush in soft, circular motions until the stain disappears. [4] X Research source You can soak your clothing for longer if you’d like. White fabric won’t be damaged by letting it soak for longer.

steps.title: Throw the clothing in with your dirty laundry and wash it.
steps.content: Throw the clothing in with your dirty laundry and wash it. Throw your item of clothing in with your dirty laundry and sort it before you wash it. Use your standard laundry detergent and run a regular wash cycle to remove any residue from your baking soda or hydrogen peroxide. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Place your item of clothing in a sink or large bowl, inside out.
steps.content: Place your item of clothing in a sink or large bowl, inside out. You’re going to soak your item of clothing for a while, so make sure that the bowl is big and deep enough to keep your clothing fully submerged for a long period of time. Place the stained area at the lowest point in the bowl or sink so that it can fully soak when you add your vinegar. [6] X Research source White vinegar is the least likely to damage colored clothing.

steps.title: Fill a bowl with white vinegar and water and pour it over the stain.
steps.content: Fill a bowl with white vinegar and water and pour it over the stain. In a large bowl, combine 1 part white vinegar with 1 part water and mix it with a large spoon. Pour your mixture over the stain so that it is fully submerged in your mixture. [7] X Research source About 1 ⁄ 3 cup (79 mL) of each ingredient will be enough for 1 shirt or pair of pants as long as this will cover the stain completely.

steps.title: Let your clothing soak for 30 minutes before washing it.
steps.content: Let your clothing soak for 30 minutes before washing it. Allow your clothing to soak in the vinegar solution for at least 30 minutes before throwing it in with your sorted laundry for a standard wash. If you notice that the stain is still there after you’ve washed it, repeat this process. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Fill a glass with water and lemon juice.
steps.content: Fill a glass with water and lemon juice. Squeeze several lemons into a small glass until it’s half full. Then, top the lemon juice off with room temperature water until your glass is filled to the brim. You can add 1 teaspoon (4 grams) of salt to the mixture if you’d like to make the stain easier to scrub. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Pour your lemon juice solution onto the stain and rub it.
steps.content: Pour your lemon juice solution onto the stain and rub it. With your item of clothing sitting over your sink, pour your lemon juice over your stain and begin to rub it gently between the pads of your fingers. Rub it for 3-5 minutes until you see the stain disappearing. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Leave your clothing to soak for 1 hour and then wash it.
steps.content: Leave your clothing to soak for 1 hour and then wash it. After you’ve rubbed the majority of the stain away, let your clothing sit in the sink for 1 hour. This will give the lemon juice and water time to loosen up any remaining residue from the sweat stain. Then, throw your clothing in with the rest of your laundry. [11] X Research source You can rinse the lemon juice and salt under cold water if you’re washing the clothing with any colored items of clothing and are worried about the salt changing their color. Lemon juice can have an undesired effect on colored fabric if it’s been dyed.
